content: got it, can we do it sometime tomorrow @fabrizioqdrant ? What hours will you be online?

hi there, from the basic example of fine tuning I learnt from the intetnet. You don't need vector db when doing fine tuning (for fine tuning you provide pair of dataset like input-output-context to the model and you trained it)(Yeah there also someguy recently puting the RAG into fine-tuning stage but that's I am not familiar with) For RAG, yeah you need vector db to do the retrieval that's the essence of RAG.
also we are working on sparse vectors, that might be something interesting for you. you can use it with models like SPLADE
but you should be careful and only put relevant words into the text query, qdrant doesn't do text processing, so you need to be cautious about stop-works and stuff like this
the scoring will still be done using vector similarities, but only on a subset of documents
yes, it is possible. In qdrant you can set filters along with vector query, so it will only return those results that include text match.

So far I am having huge problems with embeddings (tried a lot of them, from ada-2, to BGE-large and biolinkbert) that when user asks question about specific gene, or gene variant or any other entity with id the similarity search returns passages with totally different genes/variants/whatever. I wonder what would be a strategy to mitigate this? So far I am thiking if it is possible to combine fulltext search with embedding one as fulltext at least respects terminology and does not give a lot of top results for totally unrelated genes. Another can be NER recognition, the problem is that the number of NER is so huge that it is impossible to put them to metadata. What other soolutions you would suggest? So far this problem makes vector databases totally useless for me for almost a half user queries.

"Both Qdrant.from_texts and Qdrant.from_documents methods are great to start using Qdrant with Langchain. In the previous versions the collection was recreated every time you called any of them. That behaviour has changed. Currently, the collection is going to be reused if it already exists. Setting force_recreate to True allows to remove the old collection and start from scratch."

This is from official documentation, but the behavior is not as documented.

Hi there, 
I'm using the following code and expecting qdrant not to recreate index everytime I launch the app as per the documentation on langchain (https://python.langchain.com/docs/integrations/vectorstores/qdrant) .   But I see everytime qdrant taking time to recreate the index ( 3 mins per html doc) and slowing the launch. Any help is appreciated.


```
qdrant = Qdrant.from_documents(
    all_doc_splits,
    ch_embed,
    path="./local_qdrant",
    ## location=":memory:",  # Local mode with in-memory storage only
    collection_name="html_documents"
)
```

content:
> I had initially put in 5 replicas in the config, and then I changed it to 2 replicas. It was still searching for the other three replicas when it loaded up. Is that expected?

Qdrant doesn't automatically change replica layout, you would need to move shards with API if you want to introduce new machine into the cluster or delete some replicas.

> The service does not respond to search queries until and unless all the pods are not up and running. Is that expected?

Qdrant should respond as soon as at-least one replica of all shards is available

Hi @syno08! Thank you for the clear report.

I have a few questions on this to try to shrink the problem scope:
1. When this happens, does it resolve itself after some time?
2. While bulk inserting, are you also invoking other requests?
3. What does your collection configuration look like? Please share the output of `http://localhost:6333/collections/MY_COLLECTION`
4. Could you elaborate a bit on what your bulk requests look like, I'd like to reproduce this. Is it a continuous stream of 100 point upserts for example?
@null
is it possible that the connection has been idle for a very long time?
could you please send me your Qdrant Cloud cluster id via dm?

Hey. You can have UUIDs and 64 bit unsigned integers for point IDs. The string you're trying to isn't a valid UUID.
I think you can use your unique string by parsing it to a deterministic UUID.
```py
uuid = uuid.uuid5(uuid.NAMESPACE_DNS, your_unique_string
```

I am an user who is using qdrant so well.
Once again, I'd like to take this opportunity to thank everyone for making this a great product to use...
I know that you put a UUID String in the IDs item of the Points that make up the Collection, but I would like to ask if it is possible to put a 14 Byte String other than the UUID.

The other String is the _id String used by MongoDB, which is called ObjectID.

ex) ObjectId("542c2b97bac0595474108b48")

I want to use that String part instead of the UUID.

Thanks in advance

Best Regards...

5.2Gb is probbaly leftover cache form previus collections you deleted

For your configuration,

```
249001 x 1536 / 1024 / 1024 ~= 364Mb used for quantized vectors in RAM

something like ~200Mb for indexes
```

GCP Matching Engine requires 2 replicas at least to be included in their SLA.

> Would that mean that you may have to create this PV for it, instead of doing it on its own?

I think it's better to say: the cause of the PVC mismatch should be found, so the PV can be created automatically üôÇ  If for example the PVC would contain a non-existing storage class, the PV will not be created. If there is no default storage class, it won't neither. 

To gain knowledge about your storage classes, you may issue:

```
kubectl get storageclass
Then kubectl describe $STORAGECLASSNAME
```

For the record, it would also be possible to create the PV manually, but this is not in the intention of our Helm chart.
I can ask someone internally for help who is more knowledgeable on this, if youd like.

From that source:
> When none of the static PVs the administrator created matches a user‚Äôs PersistentVolumeClaim, the cluster may try to dynamically provision a volume specially for the PVC.
Would that mean that you may have to create this PV for it, instead of doing it on its own?

@hughesadam87 

>  I'm assuming we have to create these ourselves outside of the helm chart?  

No, the PVC is issued from the Helm chart and should result in a PV with the default storage class. 

A good explanation of the dependency chain of storage class, PVC and PV can be found here: https://stackoverflow.com/a/56450505.

**Reporting issues on Discord**

Before you create a report, first check whether a similar issue has already been brought up by someone else. 
Check the troubleshooting docs:
https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/common-errors/ 
Go to the GitHub issue search and look through open and closed issues. If the issue has been fixed, try to reproduce it using the latest version of Qdrant.

**Required information**

Summarize the issue. Describe what you are trying to do and how you are being blocked. Let us know what should have been the result.

Are you using Qdrant in local mode, with Docker or Qdrant Cloud? If you are using Qdrant Cloud, please provide the cluster id.

Which Qdrant version are you running? Sometimes the issue happens because you are not running the latest version.

How are you connecting to Qdrant? Are you using a client?

Provide your current database configuration. What are the current collection settings? How many vectors in a collection? In case of a distributed setup, describe shards, replication factor etc.

What is your server configuration? If your question is related to performance, we need to know the operating system version, CPU, RAM size and storage details.

Is there anything showing in the server logs? Also, provide screenshots of monitoring or log excerpts that illustrate the issue.

**Reproduce the issue**

We need reproducible code or a script that demonstrates the problem. Please give us step-by-step instructions to recreate the situation. For errors or problems with queries:
Show the exact code of the query or the request.
Paste the exact output of the response or the error message you are getting back.

Try to recreate the problem in a controlled environment. This helps you confirm that the issue is consistent. If possible, identify the specific conditions that trigger the problem.

What were you doing when the error happened? Is there a common pattern?
Have you attempted any workarounds?

and you don't need to install, maybe something is wrong with your environment

yes, qdrant-client uses sqlite3 for its local mode
afaik, sqlite3 is a builtin library in python3

i used help of @null here

memmap_threshold configures a threshold at which segments will be converted into a memory mapped segment. That segment will use a single memory mapped file for all vector data (and a second one for delete flags).

When you set on_disk=True for vectors, all segments will use memory mapping at all times. Those segments use chunks, meaning that multiple memory maps may be used for a single segment.

The first, with memmap_threshold creates immutable segments. The latter with on_disk: true creates mutable segments.
The first will be better for performance on a somewhat static collection. The latter is very good for quickly inserting a huge amount of data.

content: yes but we do not want to occupy 100s of GB in RAM as that seems a bit too much
it depends on your resources

the reason im looking at storing the vectors on disk is because of the dataset size, we are looking to store more the 40GB of data and i believe quantization of this much amount of data will not help in this case. Please do correct me if im wrong
will on_disk only store the vectors on disk or will it also occupy the ram?
ok
ok, yes the collection for some reason have not taken the declared config
also i would recommend you to remove `memmap_threshold=1` and instead set `on_disk=True`

according to your collection info
1) hnsw is not stored on disk
2) vectors are not stored on disk

before storing hnsw and vectors on disk (which can significantly reduce the performance), i would recommend you to try such techniques as quantization 

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/quantization/?selector=aHRtbCA%2BIGJvZHkgPiBkaXY6bnRoLW9mLXR5cGUoMSkgPiBzZWN0aW9uID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gZGl2ID4gYXJ0aWNsZSA%2BIGgyOm50aC1vZi10eXBlKDEp#scalar-quantization

embeds.title: Release v1.5.0 ¬∑ qdrant/qdrant
embeds.description:
Change log
Features ü™©

#1951, #2496 - Add batch update endpoint for points API
#2470 - Add binary quantization
#2410, #2562, #2571 - Add shard snapshot API
#2431, #2488 - Add indexed_only parameter...
